About Jonny Oldham


Below are some of my interests, and some thoughts about them.

Orchestral and Choral Composition

'The final aim and reason of all music is nothing other than the glorification of God and the refreshment of the spirit'

I know what you're thinking. Indeed, J.S. Bach drew his livelihood from religious institutions. Yet, what richer wellspring of inspiration exists for a composer than the pursuit of glorifying one's conception of the transcendental? The idea retains purity precisely because it is scoped by the limits of one's imagination. Above my piano hangs a portrait of the preeminent architect of sound himself. This man harbored no desire for dominance, nor excessive financial gain but rather sought the ability to empower others see beyond their physical surround. A genuine servant of music, under whose watchful gaze I strive to meticulously imbue my scores with order, color, and emotion.


I think music embodies empathy in tangible form. While we perceive it through the filter of cultural baggage, it serves as a potent means of communication between souls. Film music, in particular, holds a special place for me. When skillfully composed, it weaves a narrative more potent than words or images alone ever could. The interplay of tension and resolution, the dynamic call and response - it transforms each piece into a captivating journey, there and back again into realms of emotion. From the enchanting melodies of John Williams to the commanding textures of Zimmer, the whimsical instrumentation of John Powell to the rhythmic allure of Morricone - every great film composer leaves an indelible signature in the world. Their musical creations reflect a profound understanding of human connection. Perhaps one day people might remark, 'That sounds very Jonny Oldham,' and that there may exist a shared comprehension of what that entails drives my desire to contribute a unique voice to the tapestry of musical expression.

Stoicism and Inland Waterways

'Nothing seems really to matter, that's the charm of it'

Residing in 21st-century London, it's remarkably easy to lose one's self in the relentless pace of the urban hustle. The city's dynamic rhythm can be all-encompassing. Yet, taking a momentary step back unveils a captivating, slowly unfolding narrative of history embedded in the very foundation of our fair capital. Consider King's Cross, a microcosm where the intricate interplay of roads, railways, and waterways stands a testament to a palimpsest of centuries. Here, each era has been intricately woven into the urban fabric, creating a mosaic of time and development. Amidst the modern clamor, there lies a silent acknowledgment of the layers that constitute the city's essence. I think it's important to appreciate why a fence has been erected, before rushing to cut it down - a sentement captured wonderfully by the late Roger Scruton when he talks about 'recognizing the value of what we have, the wisdom of the past, and the need for gradual, organic change rather than radical upheaval'.


Personally, I've always been drawn to the solace found in seeking out quiet corners to walk, sit, and reflect. These moments often become an opportunity to conjure up melodies or simply let my thoughts meander. It's in the exploration of all-but-forgotten canals and waterways that I discover a reflection of my own stoic qualities. To me, this quest for insight is not about living in the past, but rather learning from it so that we not only avoid repeating the mistakes of history, but can innovate successfully armed with an illumination over how we achieved today's successes. In my view, parting with a week's wages to embody a sardine at Hyde Park's Winter Wonderland falls pale against an afternoon wandering our towpaths, contemplating the engineering of Brunel and simply observing ducks.

Vidya Gaems and Strategy

'By bolter shell, flamer burst, and melta blast, the mutant, the heretic, and the traitor alike are cleansed of their sin of existence'

Whether commanding the Space Marines to a decisive victory over the forces of Chaos, repelling the Uruk-Hai at Helm's Deep or guiding the British Empire to world domination, I've always been a keen gamer. My real passion though lies with turn-based and real-time strategy. Allocating resources, navigating technology upgrades and positioning combat units on a map is incredibly satisfying, if uninteresting to an observer. What we, as gamers, actually engage with however is more interesting. It's the pattern-recognition ability that wins the day I think. Being able to predict what a computer will do takes time. Trial and error. One can figure out what is likely to happen because computers are based on sets of rules. Predicting what a human will do.. requires skill.


Ultimately, two human gamers are still operating within the confines of a rule-based system. There are a finite number of explicit unit types, boons, resources etc. but an infinite number of ways in which they might be employed. I've found that the real trick when facing an unknown human opponent is to force them to play your game. Engage them in such a way that they are persistently on the back foot, like Rommel would. Emphasis on speed, initiative and surprise. This way, they have no time to plan and execute their own strategy, and are harrassed into withdrawal early, leaving the map's bounties to take. Lessons learned from previous encounters can be used to categorize one's enemy quickly, and base predictions upon this. If you can accurately assess how your opponent thinks, you will understand what he is likely to do next.

My Many Faces

'It's the little details that are vital. Little things make big things happen'

I began working as a supporting artist during the covid-19 pandemic, as an antedote to the spare time I suddenly found myself in posession of. I spent six months portraying a waist-gunner in the American 100th Bomb Group that fought out of east-anglia during the seocnd world war. What an incredible experience! From cheering on a pistol-initiated bike race, scrambling for cover during a night-time air-raid to bailing out of a crash-landed B-17 Flying Fortress and sprinting accross a field with cast members, it was, quite literally, an absolute blast. What an interesting lesson in group psychology too, given that a cohort of several hundred young men were chucked into a replica army base, wearing authentic uniform all day and pretending to be soldiers for months at a time. Place a weapon in a man's hand and watch the fire ignite in his belly. Did social hierarchies form? did personalities clash? were there dramatic swings of emotion felt by everyone? You bet.


Since then, I've gone on to guard the king of England in several differet centuries, serve meringues to the Bridgerton family, fight in the battle of Waterloo, faithfully serve Captain Marvel, jeer at Victorian underground boxing matches and trade my wares in King's Landing, Westeros. In total, I have been a part of 43 different TV and film productions, ranging from a single day to recurring roles across many months. I have gained an accute appreciation of the delicacy of silver trays, the weight of chain-mail armour, the uncomfortability of medieval transportation and the acerbic taste of gunpowder. What better way is there to hone one's adapatability than starting a brand new job each day, somewhere completely different, with a whole new team. Give me a tray and I'm your footman. A starched collar, your aristocrat. A musket, your hero.
